citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
An adult Umbrella Cockatoo "Zeus" who is singly housed, but within eyesight and earshot of other birds, is showing signs
of psychological distress in appearance through plucking and damaging its chest feathers. Zeus does not have written
documentation of additional environmental enhancement approved by the attending veterinarian in the environment
enhancement plan. In discussion with the attending veterinarian, they confirmed with the inspectors that the bird is
showing these signs due to psychogenic factors. Failure to address signs of being in psychological distress in birds
through additional environmental enhancement in accordance with attending veterinarian instructions may result in
continued or worsening signs of affected animals.
Certain birds must be provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment in accordance with the
instructions of the attending veterinarian, including those that show signs of being in psychological distress through
behavior or appearance.
Correct by 16 May 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
TYLER FIELDS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.154(c)(2) 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
An adult Umbrella Cockatoo "Zeus" who is singly housed, but within eyesight and earshot of other birds, is showing signs 
of psychological distress in appearance through plucking and damaging its chest feathers. Zeus does not have written 
documentation of additional environmental enhancement approved by the attending veterinarian in the environment 
enhancement plan. In discussion with the attending veterinarian, they confirmed with the inspectors that the bird is 
showing these signs due to psychogenic factors. Failure to address signs of being in psychological distress in birds 
through additional environmental enhancement in accordance with attending veterinarian instructions may result in 
continued or worsening signs of affected animals. 
 
Certain birds must be provided special attention regarding enhancement of their environment in accordance with the 
instructions of the attending veterinarian, including those that show signs of being in psychological distress through 
behavior or appearance. 
 
Correct by 16 May 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
TYLER FIELDS, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
